body: @bvaradar The build is failing due to OOM on jenkins. How did you fix it last time ?
Just realized - does it mean HoodieKey might not be unique in the table since insert may accept duplicate records?

>>Not sure if it makes sense to extend this deduping to more index types than  
yes. but not all indexes may be able to support global de-duping. So like to leave them decoupled and just advice user on what index to use when.. 

In a nutshell, we use Hive (ETL), Spark (ML/Data science/ETL), Presto (interactive queries).. :)

spark datasource can now sync to hive..
I had some changes based on discussion in #441, please let me know if it make sense to add that code into this PR or better to make a separate PR for that.

>Just realized - does it mean HoodieKey might not be unique in the table since insert may accept duplicate records?

both insert and bulk_insert assume that the input data won't contain any duplicates. if it does, then use upsert() . For your use case., we can call tagLocation() -> filter out dupes -> insert() / bulkInsert() .. this is how we use it.. 

This is more efficient than upsert() for the de-duping case, since it avoid updating the same data again.
@bvaradar any initial thoughts?

@sungjuly @n3nash :  Thanks a lot for providing the feedback. I have revamped this PR and made few improvements. Here is the list:

1. Reimplement docker files to reduce image sizes. I am seeing 3-4x improvements in docker sizes (from 4 - 5 GB to 0.8-1.5GB). 
2. I have published all the docker images to docker-hub (temporarily using my docker-hub account) so that there is no need to build the docker images as part of running the script. 
3. Made both docker images and compose follow convention so that a single image can satisfy both use-cases
   (a) Standalone - Docker images that are published to Docker-hub have inbuilt hudi jars so that they are self-contained.
  (b) Mounting Convention - The images allow for overriding those hudi jars with locally built jars allowing for the same setup to be used for running integ-testing against code-changes locally (look at the compose script and hoodie-integ/pom.xml)
4.  Updates quickstart docs to reflect the changes above

I have marked this PR as WIP since I need to showcase  incremental view as part of demo. 

@n3nash @sungjuly : Can you please follow the quickstart steps and let me know your experience. 
Our aim is to have an easy-to-use and hassle-free hudi quickstart. I would appreciate your feedback on that.

@leletan Please squash the commits and let me know when the diff is ready. I understand the cyclic dependency on HoodieTestUtils so let's avoid that. Please see if there are utils that you can reuse for creating datafiles etc (instead of creating them in the code as you have right now). We can get this diff landed soon.

Thanks for your quick response !!

I have seen location attribute is set correctly. I did typo in DDL statement. Please find describe formatted details as below:

Here table 'hoddie_test' is pointing to HDFS location -> 'hdfs://nameservice1/user/bdp/hoodie-test'.

 

My use case is to optimize existing Hive table in which data is getting ingested from informatica jobs.

Do I have to use 'HoodieWriteClient API' to ingest the data into Hoodie table ?

 

I have just added below to two jar files in Hive for Hoodie table.

 

hive> add jar file:///hoodie-poc/hoodie-common-0.4.5-SNAPSHOT.jar;

hive> add jar file:///hoodie-poc/hoodie-hadoop-mr-0.4.4-SNAPSHOT.jar;

 

Do I have to follow some more steps to setup Hoodie Hive environment in my CDH cluster ?

 

Please help !

@AnkitMishra3220 :

"My use case is to optimize existing Hive table in which data is getting ingested from informatica jobs."
      We have a pending PR which details how to migrate existing tables to Hoodie. Here is the link : https://github.com/uber/hudi/blob/fda78e40ad6c0e18015610e5403858fea06a9634/docs/migration_guide.md
     Let me know if you have more question around this. We will be happy to help you.

"Do I have to use 'HoodieWriteClient API' to ingest the data into Hoodie table ?"
  Hoodie ingestion path requires using a spark job to incrementally ingest data to the data-set. 
  As you can notice from the quickstart ( here : https://uber.github.io/hudi/quickstart.html#step-2-incrementally-ingest-data-from-kafka-topic), we have a ready-to-use Spark tool - HoodieDeltaStreamer to ingest data. This supports ingesting from common data-sources like kafka.
  This tool uses HoodieWriteClient API to ingest data.  If you have a different (custom) data-source, you can directly use HoodieWriteClient API to ingest (Take a look at DeltaStreamer source to understand how this is done).
  The read-path is supported by both Hive and Spark.

"Do I have to follow some more steps to setup Hoodie Hive environment in my CDH cluster ?"
 We had revamped the quickstart to include a demo. Not sure if you got a chance to look at the latest version of quickstart ( https://uber.github.io/hudi/quickstart.html ). From your hive console dump, it looks like you are not using the correct jar. The quickstart should give you the context.

Hi @vinothchandar, I am working with @cb149 on applying Hudi in our production. We are looking for supporting DeltaStreamer for parquet. Is this duplicated with #429 which is about generalizing data source by using Spark data source API? 

My question is also how hard is refactoring the code by using spark datasource api v2 fashion.
BTW, Could we wrap DFSSource for Parquet to ingest delta part (like `AvroDFSSource` does) for a temporary solution?
can we add a unit test or add a check to an existing test confirming props are carried over.. Given a large reliance on this, I think its best to do this before checking in
lg otherwise
lg
@leletan looks good. merging.. sorry for the delay. was OOO

I put this code for some real data set testing and it seems working. Not sure what is the best way to add tests. 
My instinct would be adding something to DataSourceTest, but all tests there are batch based.

May I have some high level advices on how to test this in the repo?
Thanks @vinothchandar
Hi @vinothchandar, what's the status of this ticket? I guess it involves what we want to shift to datasource api v2.

#429 has some open issues which I don't know how to proceed.. 
 
I think the short term approach for parquet source makes sense to me.. @bvaradar is currently doing some work on an `HoodieIncrementalSource`, which consumes incrementally from an upstream hoodie dataset. Would this help with your usecase? 

Or do you need source as raw parquet files? I vaguely remember discussing an alternate solution for use case with someone on slack (not sure if its @cb149) .. Let's assume you are currently reading from source system X (which may be kafka, kinesis..) and writing out parquet. Instead of reading these parquet files and writing using deltastreamer (your ask in this issue), could be just have deltastreamer read from X directly and write a hoodie dataset? Then, it also becomes easy to compare the two datasets (plain parquet and hoodie) head-head for freshness, correctness etc.. 

if above don't suffice, yes. Happy to support a `ParquetDFSSource` . Let me know.. :)

Thank you @vinothchandar ! 

Consuming incrementally from an upstream hoodie dataset might not be in our usecase. Since, we still need to do one-time parquet import for incremental changes periodically.

For our case, we dump avro messages in Kafka to HDFS (parquet files) by using Kafka Connect. As you said, we could directly have `deltastreamer` to read Avro from Kafka using `AvroKafkaSource`. I will try this first. If it doesn't work, I'll try to support a `ParquetDFSSource`.

Let me understand the PR and will get back to you..
it seems this likely as per design, just to double confirm
Thanks
@n3nash @vinothchandar : when you get a chance, please review this.
netty is a transitive dependency coming from hadoop-hdfs and spark-core. Since both are provided packages, we need to exclude them from bundle jars
